#### Reference Issues/PRs
#3865

Clarify tenure ending CC and CoC

body:
@aiwalter, I think the implication that sktime governance is undemocratic is wholly inappropriate. We have a representative decision making system and voting.

This is also not sufficiently addressing problems we have seen recently emerge in discussion culture.

I think these parallel issues that wikipedia is seeing, especially things like hounding, single-issue vote piling by people who do not really contribute to the community.

The key parallel concept would be "clearly not being here to build a package":
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Here_to_build_an_encyclopedia#Clearly_not_being_here_to_build_an_encyclopedia

Related issues:

* https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Civil_POV_pushing
* https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:POV_Railroad

I didnt say the governance in undemocratic in general, but there are parts of it that are clearly undemocratic as mentioned above. The general idea of this issue is to give more power to the core developers, who are the main representatives of the community.
You are making PR that abolish separation of duties/powers and strongly imply that we are currently undemocratic.

"clearly undemocratic" is a misrepresentation of how representative democracies and multi-chamber systems work.

Democratic does not mean that a given person always get what they want. In representative democracies like the one you live in, it does not even mean that the majority always gets what it wants.

This is a populist move, and possibly plan to seize control of sktime.

Given [current conflicts of interest](https://github.com/sktime/community-org/blob/main/community_council/previous_meetings/20221108-meeting.md) I ask you to refrain from trying to completely rewrite the decision making mechanisms of sktime.

Especially:

* trying to effectively remove independence of the entity that investigate CoC incidents
* trying to rewrite the rules that allow you to kick other people out quickly

rename.to: [GOV] major change proposal to sktime governance

-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
#3865


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
This adds separation of power between CC and CoC. A person should not be able to have the two positions at same time due to separation of power. This is a typical principle of democracy.

body: @fkiraly can you pls kindly not rename my PR titles, thx. If you think the title is not appropriate, pls comment here why.

> @fkiraly can you pls kindly not rename my PR titles, thx. If you think the title is not appropriate, pls comment here why.

Description should refer to the specific proposed changes and not just vaguely label this as "democratization".

There is also an implication that governance is not democratic, which is inappropriate.

Please do not revert the title change, or at least address the inappropriate implication.

body: With respect, you want to abolish separation of powers/duties. That is not democratic.

> bit childish what you are doing?

stop the insults please.

this is just basic "title should accurately reflect the content" policy, I have also explained to you the negative impication of the title.

issue.title: [GOV] recent GOV proposals - how to proceed

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
We need to ensure that we proceed correctly on recent suggested changes to `sktime` decision making, both from a procedural perspective and from an accountability perspective.

We need to ensure:

* that we preserve [separation of powers/duties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_of_duties), removing them would weaken accountability and enable corruption. A combination of recent proposed measures can lead to concentration of powers, as follows: [making the core dev vote override policy decisions](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3867), and making the [core devs the last authority in appointments](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3866) (these being in two separate PR makes it harder to see)
* changes ensure governance is representative for the `sktime` community or the user community - among core devs there are large single issue groups, and the `sktime` contributor community has long outgrown its narrow roots in few academic research groups. Making the core dev vote the single vote that overrides all would in consequence disenfranchise minorities in the active contributor community, especially when combined with removing any mutual checks between committees.
* we need to ensure that the process is consensus based and takes place in regular developer and CC meetings. Recent lapses in attendance of these meetings are problematic, and procedural norms of the past years would require substantial changes to be presented in said meetings.
* there are recent discussions on code of conduct and resource allocations decisions which should be resolved first: https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3674. Otherwise, decisions that (directly or indirectly) remove power from the code of conduct committee, or remove its independence, could easily be interpreted as massive conflicts of interest.
* on `sktime` internal channels this has caused heated discussions and behaviour that, in my opinion, was unacceptable. No matter the nature of proposed changes, this needs to stop before we engage with change requests to the governance models. If we are to consider these proposals, it must happen in an environment that is not charged with emotion, fear and hurt.

In particular, if we want to make sweeping changes like this, I think we need more than just push these through a core dev or CC vote of whatever majorities there are.

I think this requires at least:

* a workshop where all core devs are properly briefed of pros/cons; ample opportunity for Q&A before any change is made, at least in the order of months
* multiple readings in transparently minuted CC meetings. Core developers needs to start attending the CC meetings again and adhere to the process of minuting and minute confirmation.
* de-escalation of any combative dynamics in internal `sktime` channels
* sufficient room for critical voices, e.g., to explain how the multiple PR in combination erode separation of duties or corruption checks

Content-wise, we need to consider and discuss clearly:

* if we introduce more direct elements of democracy, who is the electorate? Should it perhaps not be active users and contributors, e.g., on slack, rather than just the core developer group? For example: our users are international, and there is a strong skew towards the UK and lack of diversity in `sktime`'s academic core developers.
* if we introduce term limits, should there not also be proper elections, at regular intervals? Rather than just having run term limits running out one by one until there is just one CC member left (or none in the end)?
* how do proposed changes affect checks and balances, e.g., ability of a coordinated small group of people seize `sktime` assets and lock everyone else out?
* how do proposed changes affect the CoC committee's ability to deal with bullying and harassment, especially targeted at minorities?
* who oversees proper conduct of elections if separation of duties is abolished?

These are hard and serious questions, so we cannot just rush these changes through.

body: @aiwalter, @patrickzib, kindly take note of the last paragraph in this issue on how I will enforce the code of conduct in public discussion spaces such as this: https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3882#issuecomment-1336287948
